Marco Baroni writes:
> > Note that this excludes ".au", which can be problematic if you are
> > fetching documents from domains in Australia, since the DNS request
> > gets filtered and this is a required prerequisite, so the entire site
> > gets filtered.
> 
> How comes Australia is filtered out?

'au' is the ISO 3166 country code for Australia, so top-level domains
using ".au" get filtered out when the DNS request is made. As a file
suffix ".au" is usually used for audio files, which I do not want to
include in my text-only crawls.

> Once I understand more about Heritrix, I would be happy to help out with
> the project of integrating BootCat-like seeding methods into it.

Cool --- we can talk about that offline and then come back to the list
later if things work out.

> (Right now, I seem to have out of memory problems, having tried a broad 
> scope crawl... still a lot to learn! ;-) )

Yes, broad scope is a huge memory hog. Work is going on right now to
use different methods for storing the discovered URLs. Until then I'd
avoid using broad scope.

For my Traditional Chinese crawl we manually collected around 100 URLs
and are using a host scope to limit the spread. One problem that I've
run into doing these data crawls in the past has been contamination
from external links to adverts and the like. Limiting to the hosts in
the seed list help with this. Unfortunately 100 seeds isn't really
enough: my current crawl has been running for 502 hours and is only
55% complete with 3 queues ... I'll probably kill it eventually, but
for now I continue to let it run since I don't need to crawl anything
else right now.
